newsitem.title: UK: INSIGHT -T-bonds to move steadily down to 106-22.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT -T-bonds to move steadily down to 106-22.

text.p: June T-bond futures are set to maintain their bearish outlook and head down towards 106-22 on Tuesday, technical analysts said.

"Really it's a case of the market being in a steady bear trend looking for the next leg down and selling the corrective rallies when they come along," said David Sneddon, technical analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in London. "The big target we are looking for here is 106-23, 106-22 with interim support at 107 the figure, which is a potential channel support."
At 0944 GMT, June T-bonds were at 107-07, unchanged from Monday's Chicago close in automated trade.

"Near-term you've got resistance at 107-19, 107-21," said Sneddon. "If it gets above there we could see a bit of a correction back to around 108-00, but it should really hold below 108-04 to preserve the immediate bearish structure."
Daily charts show 108-04 was the low on March 26.
On initial tests, 106-23, 22 would likely hold and there could be a rebound or some sideways consolidation, Sneddon said.
"But I expect the market to eventually break below that area and see a move to the 106-02, 105-28 band," he said.
Nicholas Rose, technical analyst at 4CAST in London, also saw downward pressure on T-bonds but sought an initial rally.

"At the moment they are in quite a flat range at the lows struck last Thursday and the important test is going to be to the upside early on. But any (upside) tests should sell back as T-bonds are still weak on a daily basis," Rose said. "The basic pattern is to sell this rally but looking for a base to come in sometime this week."
He said initial support was at 107-05, Monday's low, but the contract had the potential to get down to 107-00.
Below there, the next main level at 106-00 was not an impossible target for this session, he said although he expected an initial move higher.
"Things look pretty choppy at the moment with the moves in the stock market, and there is an air of worry," Rose said.
September Eurodollars were trading at 93.690, up 0.005 from Monday's Chicago settlement.
